[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

INVESTIGATION INTO LEAKAGE
OF SECRET INCOME TAX
INFORMATION
(Commission of Inquiry)


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question (18th March, 1959),

    "That, in view of the leakage of secret income-tax information as evidenced in the Assembly debate on the 4th of March, 1959, and in view of the resulting public anxiety regarding the safety of all the secret or confidential information about the general public entrusted to the Income Tax Department, this Assembly is of the opinion that a Commission of Inquiry should be appointed to investigate into and report on the circumstances in which

Column: 2259

particulars of file No. 47909/GS of the Income Tax Department became available to a person not entitled thereto.-(Mr Lee Choon Eng).

    Question again proposed.

10.02 a.m.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday we condemned those who were responsible for the leakage. I know that all hon. Members in this House as well as all right-thinking people of Singapore will join us in such condemnation.

    But I certainly feel, Sir, that we do not only deplore such a class of people but also the other side of those who are involved. I am referring to those who have urged or who have been using such officials to make them divulge such secret information. Those who corrupt the civil servants are also guilty of that offence. Between the two, those who have bribed or have attempted to corrupt these people should deserve greater punishment.

    We have many laws in Singapore concerning this. I know that if a person should bribe a police constable and if that matter is reported, then that person too will be punished by the law. I feel that, as this matter is of such grave consequence, those who are involved should also be punished.

    The information before us is that the hon. Member for Tanjong Pagar has come forward with such information. Where has he got the news? Who has been instrumental in getting that news? Who has been edging on the civil servants to be disloyal to the Government which they serve?

    Was it from higher officials who have had access to the files, or was it, as alleged by the hon. Mr Thomas, by way of bringing files in and out and somebody who was responsible or who has had access to the files having a look at it

    Mr Francis Thomas (Nominated) rose -

    Mr Speaker: Is it a point of order?

Column: 2260



    Mr Francis Thomas: Point of explanation, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: If the Member will give way.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong resumed his seat.

    Mr Francis Thomas: I want to say that I did not allege anything yesterday (that I recollect) at all. I described various possibilities but I did not allege how the particular leakage of the information coming out from the Income Tax Department came about. I did not allege any particular method by which it got out.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: I am grateful for his explanation, Sir. But whatever it is, this concerns a matter which, we would say, is top secret. The people who have access to such files are few. People who have influence over such files are fewer still. We would say that, in all probability, it might be those who have always been passing information from one side to the other - from the Government side to the Opposition, or from one party to the other. That may be so. I am also just suggesting a method whereby it may be leaked out. If such were so, it should be fully investigated. I personally have a very low opinion of those who indulge in such operations, if such men have no honour, they should be better out of the political field or even out of our own country.

    We have men who say that their whole life is devoted towards promoting the welfare of Singapore. Now we have information that there are quite a number of people who are not. We demand complete loyalty even from those who come to live with us and want to become citizens. Who wants to set examples to them? We want to make them feel that they are following leaders who have integrity, and who are going to make them feel that they are living with leaders in whom they can have faith and to whom they can even close their eyes and be led along. But if we have leaders who force civil servants who have all the time been loyal, to be disloyal,

Column: 2261

who have all the time been cheating on procedures when secrecy is essential, then such men. I would say, are the very scum of Singapore.

    I suggest, Sir, that the Commission of Inquiry, when it inquires into this matter, should have this question foremost in their minds, to establish the identities of those who have made possible the leakage of such information.

    One other point, Sir, that I would like to mention is that, on this side of the House, we want an inquiry. On the Opposition side, we have one Member who did not want the inquiry to carry on. Similarly, Sir, during the sitting early this month-the 4th of March -we also had the Opposition Party, the People's Action Party, taking a similar stand of wanting to have an inquiry and then wanting to drop it. If a matter is of such importance that a Commission of Inquiry should be called upon, then that inquiry should carry on. We do not want just to indulge in speculation. We do not want to establish any allegation where possibly there is no truth. In an instance like this, Sir, we know that the matter is wrong. It must be investigated and we must get to the bottom of it. Similarly. Sir, in the other inquiry we know that it would be wrong not to pursue it, because there could be innocent parties who would be involved and who would be blamed in this Assembly where there is privilege; but if they have an inquiry, they may prove their innocence.

    I bring up this point, Sir, because I feel in the other inquiry, too, allegations have been made as to how the funds came about. But I would say, Sir, like the Member for Tanjong Pagar, that there is no crime in receiving any political gift. What he is concerned about is whether the funds came from any foreign sources. I am certain that even if there was such a gift, and even if people did help the former Labour Front-

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the hon. Member was correct up to the point where he mentioned the former inquiry or the former motion in passing. But

Column: 2262

he seems to be developing his argument on those lines and, of course, he is going very, very far from this present motion.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: I am grateful for your guidance, Sir, I was saying that the difference between those two cases is that we want to get at the truth. I have faith in all inquiries. In passing also. Sir, I would like to mention the inquiry that looked into the matter of corrupt practices, involving the political figures during the Cairnhill by-election. There, we find that the inquiry gave us a picture that it was not the accused that was right. Neither the accused was right nor those who were accused were right, in fact, there was blame apportioned to so many people. Some people may take it that, after a court of inquiry, when the findings are not in their favour, that court of inquiry is not good. But I am of the opinion that when we appoint a court of inquiry we must abide by their findings.

    I am certain, Sir, that this court of inquiry when appointed will reveal many other things of greater interest to the people of Singapore. It will also expose a great deal of intrigue and false allegations in one case, and probably reveal the true substance of what we want to find in other cases.

    Sir, this leakage I feel is not just a leakage. I think it is also a system of spying amongst your own friends, amongst your own people. If this system were allowed to carry on and be fostered, there would be a time when we should not be able to speak to our next-door neighbour nor even to our children. There would be no secret whatsoever.

    We have had instances of this in Singapore most recently. The rot is slowly setting in. We must stop the rot. Cure it, or throw it out of Singapore as a method alien to this land, as a method that will create a lot of mistrust.

    We have, Sir, in Singapore instances of people using their political influence and asking their drivers to go against their employers when the employees

Column: 2263

probably have not even a single complaint. We have again, Sir, in unions, where spying is going on, giving information to parties or political parties that are not in their favour or the unions, and where union officials get into great trouble with the political power in the City Council. We have much more than that. The rot does not just end there. We have, even in the major political parties in Singapore, officials who impart information to Opposition members, telling them their inner secrets and giving them all the ammunition to shoot at the party they lead!

    Singapore, Sir, demands absolute loyalty of its citizens to the state. Anybody who is not loyal to this land should go to lands where their loyalty belongs. But he should not clothe himself in sheep's clothing, and come and mingle with us to destroy us. This motion has arisen from the allegations made by the leader of the People's Action Party. They have much explanations to offer to the people of Singapore. They have much to let us know who those involved were. We do not want the people of Singapore just to stop thinking at the income tax level of the inquiry. We want them to think of their own lives, of the lives in the community, of the friends they have, of the children they have. Are they going to have that spying system coming to Singapore to destroy them? I am certain the people of Singapore will take this matter seriously. They must retain here what they have today and not go back to the time of Syonanto, as Singapore was called during the occupation, when they were afraid. You were ruled by fear. You just did not know when the Kempeitai, the Japanese Military Police, would take you away from your home, just because you inadvertently said something unpleasant to the ruling power.

    I feel, Sir, that it is time the people of Singapore should wake up to eradicate those who are always instigating men against men, race against race, and doing a great disservice to this country.

Column: 2264



    Sir, the inquiry must go on. The truth must be got at. Whether the truth is pleasant or unpleasant, let those who are responsible for all these things be punished most suitably.

10.18 a.m.

    Mr A. R. Lazarous (Farrer Park): Sir, it is surprising that a Member from the Government back bench is bringing up the motion. In my opinion, it is to censure the Government. Information was leaked out from the Income Tax Department and the Minister in charge is a Government Minister - the Financial Secretary. The Financial Secretary should take the necessary action for the leakage.

    Sir, when you bring in a motion, that automatically means you are censuring the Financial Secretary and subsequently the Government.

    Sir, I will support this motion. It is not because of the calling for an inquiry. It is firstly, because it is censuring the Financial Secretary and the Government for their incompetence and bungling. Secondly, for the leakage of information. It is admitted that a civil servant has leaked out certain information and he should be punished. I agree, but let us evaluate the information against the crime he has committed. The information released was that our former Minister for Education had received $500,000 from some source. Well, to receive $500,000, he must have sold some information or render some service to foreign people, otherwise no fool is going to give him $500,000 for nothing. He must have made a promise to give certain service to that foreign force. But what is the service? Service against the interests of the population of Singapore. So it is a question of selling the service of 1,500,000 people and receiving $500,000 by an individual - one Minister. So when you count the Civil -

    Mr Speaker: I was just wondering whether the hon. Member is anticipating the findings of the Commission of Inquiry that is to be set up. Because if he is. perhaps he is straying away from the motion.

Column: 2265



    Mr Lazarous: Sir, before I started talking I had submitted that it was an allegation. As this motion involves a leakage and what was the content of the leakage, I was forced to say something about that. If I had anything to do with the Government who are going to be responsible to the Commission for the findings or the judgment, I would rather commend the man who had leaked out that information than reprimand him . Because through that information, the citizens of Singapore had gained certain information that their interests were to be sold for a few hundred thousand dollars, by a Minister, and it is the Minister for Education and the Minister responsible for leakages-

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy rose-

    Mr Speaker: Point of order?

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Sir, in the Member's speech he says it was as a Minister that the sum was received. I do not think that that allegation was made in this House. The allegation made was that he received it as a politician, as a leader of a political party. Now the hon. Member is imputing that he received it as a Minister, which means that the Government was a party to it.

    Mr Speaker: That strictly, of course, is not a point of order. It is a question of degree. Whether or not a Minister is responsible for some dereliction of duty, and whether the Government itself is to blame is a matter of opinion. I rule that it is not a point of order.

    Mr Lazarous: Sir, I still submit then, leave alone the Inquiry Commission, does the House consider the seriousness of that offence? One party, that is the civil servant, committed an offence by revealing certain information. But we must also consider what was that information. How does it affect the interests of the people? Actually, we all admit that that particular information was to the detriment of 1,500,000 people-

Column: 2266



    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the hon. Member is now anticipating what the findings might be. I think he should not proceed on those lines.

    Mr Lazarous: Sir, I shall not proceed on that any further. But my only comment is that, comparing the seriousness of the information of the leakage and the seriousness of the substance contamed, I think that that civil servant has done a duty to the people of Singapore. The particular civil servant who revealed that particular information - I must tell him that it was an offence and that he did something wrong - but you see the seriousness of the information that he has given to the public of Singapore. And it is my opinion that that civil servant, having regard to the information they received from him, has done a service to the people of Singapore.

    An hon. Member: Shame!

10.25 a.m.

    The Chief Secretary (Mr E. B. David): Sir, I have really been shocked to hear the proposition put forward by the hon. Member for Farrer Park that a civil servant who has signed an oath of secrecy in respect of all matters committed to his charge should be entitled to judge - and this is the gravamen - from the nature of that information whether or not he is entitled to produce it to any third unentitled party. I hope the House, in the interests of the integrity of the civil service, will join me in repudiating in no mean terms any such suggestion.

    Sir, the hon. Mr Francis Thomas has suggested that there is a lot of ado about nothing in this matter and that there is really no distinction between the leakage, which is the subject of this motion, and the type of Press leakage, which I must agree with him is all too common. But I think there is a fundamental difference between these two. It often happens that the Press by their own means are apt to obtain access to information or a Government intention or proposal in advance of the time when the Government intends to release it. That may be at times embarrassing. But it does not

Column: 2267

go further than that. But I do suggest to him that there is a very great difference between that type of leakage and a leakage where there may or there may not have been a deliberate breach of his oath by a civil servant, and where the public are entitled to be assured that any information made available in connection with their income tax assessments is kept secret, not just for a few days, but for all time.

    My hon. friend the Financial Secretary will, I have no doubt, be informing the House that as soon as it became clear that there had been a leakage he at once put in hand a departmental investigation. But I must point out to the House that a departmental investigation, and it is not yet complete, does have its limitation. Where the parties concerned are solely members of the department or Government servants, then it may be possible to clear the matter up and arrive at the truth. But where there are members of the public concerned, they are not of course compellable witnesses for the purpose of a departmental investigation, and if the information is particularly in their possession which would enable an inquiry of this kind to be brought to a successful conclusion, then the departmental investigation can be completely frustrated if they are not willing to come forward. Hon. Members will remember that that was the situation in relation to the investigation of the leakage of examination papers in the Chinese Middle School examinations. As I see it at present, it is still a matter for speculation as to how this leakage occurred. It may have been a matter of carelessness; it may have been a matter of negligence, or it may have been that a civil servant was deliberately responsible. The matter clearly needs to be explained and the public anxiety to be satisfied. If the hon. Member for Tanjong Pagar is taking part in this debate later, I hope he will deal with that particular point.

10.29 a.m.

    The Acting Financial Secretary (Mr Oon Khye Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are two points that I would like to speak on.

Column: 2268



    First with regard to the Department. There is need for confidentiality of information in the Department. There has been public concern over the disclosures that were made at the last sitting on 4th March and it is important that the name of the Department should be cleared. In view of the requirement for official secrecy in the Ordinance, I formed an investigation team to institute a departmental inquiry. It started only last week and it is therefore not in a position to report. Hon. Members will be quite aware of the limitation that this team will be faced with as it has to depend upon voluntary evidence. It is not likely that it will make a positive report. However, should the Assembly decide that a Commission of Inquiry be formed, the report of this team, when submitted, will be made available to the Commission.

    Sir, may I take this opportunity to clarify the misunderstanding that has arisen out of my answer to a supplementary question asked by the Member for Tanjong Pagar on 3rd March? I refer to a cyclostyled copy of the statement that was circulated to the hon. Members. The hon. Member asked:

    "Will the Financial Secretary tell us whether the Minister in question personally saw the Comptroller of Income Tax, who is now away on leave, and as a result of that interview investigations were dropped?"

My answer was:

    "That is not correct."

The intention of my answer was that investigations were not stopped as a result of the interview between the Minister and Mr Holloway. I was quoted by the hon. Member to have said that Mr Chew never saw Mr Holloway and this statement was repeated, I think, by the Member for Changi yesterday. I would like to clarify the position.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): What is the position?

    Mr Oon Khye Kiang: As explained, my answer was in reply to your question that-

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Did Mr Chew see Mr Holloway?

    Mr Speaker: Order.

Column: 2269



    Mr Oon Khye Kiang: No, I took the question as a whole, but I think the hon. Member took my answer as an answer to a part of the question, which was not my intention. Whatever is the truth of the matter, I did not state that Mr Chew never saw Mr Holloway.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: On a point of information, Sir. Will the Financial Secretary do us the courtesy of stating, as a matter of fact, that according to his information now, Mr Chew did see Mr Holloway but that, in his opinion, was not the direct reason for the stopping of the inquiry? Is that the position?

    Mr Oon Khye Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I explained, my answer was in reply to the hon. Member's question as a whole.

10.33 a.m.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Sir, as twilight over this Assembly, there is a streak of insanity in the air.

    Looting took place in a protected area. The looting was known by someone outside the protected area and Members of this Assembly, who are supposed to be representatives of the people, held up their hands in horror and in mock indignation, not at the fact of the looting but at the fact that it was known outside the protected area, We did not hear the Member for Queenstown or the Member for Paya Lebar or the Member for Serangoon, when the issue of the $500,000 was debated, but now the cry is for shame that that should ever have been made known. Sir, it was a calculated and deliberate act when I read out the file number to prove two things - that it is one thing for the Government to expect loyalty from civil servants, but that it is another thing when the Financial Secretary, in pursuance of the orders from his elected Ministers, makes a statement which he knows to be partially incorrect. We did not expect that kind of conduct.

    Sir, there is almost an air of comedy about this motion. This is a Government matter. If the Government wants to have a Commission of Inquiry, there is no necessity to move a motion in this Assembly. Press on with it, but

Column: 2270

this of course is a diversion. Everybody was aghast and flabbergasted that this thing should have been known and the best way of distracting attention is to talk about how it came to be known. Sir, at the proper time and in the proper place, we shall let it be known how it came to be known. But I will say this: if you expect, as we expect, integrity in the service, you must have Ministers to set the pace. Anyone who goes into any of the Government Ministries can smell the decay and feel the sense of collapse of morale. That is bad, because we have to run the same machine and it is our duty to stiffen up the morale. That was the reason why we gave the file number. Does the Financial Secretary realise that anybody can pick up the telephone - but: not now, because there is such a jolt in the Income Tax Department that nobody will say anything - and say, "I am Mr So and So. Will you please give me my file number?" And they do. The Income Tax Department literally speaks to the public over the phone and gives a man's file number. I have tried it, before they made this an issue. How do I come to know this? I can tell the Financial Secretary and the Chief Secretary a few other things. I know that this departmental inquiry has been going on, as it ought to be without waiting for a resolution of this Assembly. I know that Mr Teo Kah Leong and Mr Pepper (the Comptroller-General of Income Tax) have been doing a departmental inquiry, and I know that they have shortlisted it to three or four gentlemen. I would like to inform them that they have got the wrong people. They are not involved. How do I know it? It is my business to know what is going on in this Government, otherwise we would not have survived. I say this: we will keep on knowing what is going on right to the end, and it is because we know what is going on that I am going to move the next motion which is down for debate today.

    Sir, I have no objections to a Commission of Inquiry. I think the Chief Secretary knows exactly what the results will be. I am only sorry that the

Column: 2271

Government, instead of taking the bull by the horns, and making the decision themselves, have chosen to allow a Back-Bencher to moot the point in this Assembly. In the course of this Inquiry - be it one or two - let it never be forgotten that our sense of morality should not get perverted. What was really disgraceful was the deliberate lie and denial before we produced the evidence. I spent a great deal of the time of this Assembly at its last sitting in giving details just to make sure that this House and the public understand, Sir, that before we make an assertion of fact, we have ascertained its accuracy. In my position as leader of an Opposition political Party, I get a lot of information - some confidential, some very confidential, and most highly explosive. I do not use it unless I am sure of it. I will just give you an example, Mr Speaker, Sir. The moment the motion on Mr Chew Swee Kee was on, I received many letters giving me more details of that transaction, it was a political gift. We thought well of the civil service, and believed they acted properly. Therefore, they must have satisfied themselves that it was a political gift not liable to income tax. But according to information which I have now received from the post, it says, "You can check it up by advertising so and so and then I shall cross-check and prove further by giving you further information."

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): On a point of order. Sir. The question of the $500,000 is now in the hands of a Commission of Inquiry. Is it in order for the Member for Tanjong Pagar now to review facts which may prejudice the findings of that Commission?

    Mr Speaker: My understanding is that facts have not as yet been revealed. They have been threatened to be revealed. If they are revealed, then of course that is wrong. The moment we reach the stage of a threat, perhaps the Member for Tanjong Pagar will not step over the brink.

Column: 2272



    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: I do not profess to be as clever as Mr Dulles at brinksmanship. But we go as far as we can justify ourselves. It is only when we have cross-checked our information and we are positive about it that we make a firm assertion.

    Sir, a few foolish remarks were made yesterday about civil servants being threatened to give all their secrets. I do not think the Member for Paya Lebar understands what the business of Government is. I would like to make our position quite clear. If and when we are the Government, the civil service will have no secrets from the Ministers. It is the business of the Ministers to run the Government, not the civil service. and if the Member for Paya Lebar knew what the business of Government is, he would not have been responsible for such an inane remark as to suggest that it is wrong for a Minister to know what is happening.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I suppose the word "inane" in that context must be unparliamentary. I ask the hon. Member to withdraw that word.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, with respect, I am not suggesting that the hon. Member is inane. I am suggesting that the remark is inane, but if you so rule, then so be it.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I suppose that if a remark emanates from an hon. Member, the hon. Member must be tainted with that remark, and therefore I ask the hon. Member to withdraw that word.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: As you please, Mr Speaker, Sir, I withdraw it; but nevertheless I should have thought that the elementary principle of the law of defamation says that you cannot impute stupidity in a man but you can always impute stupidity in the remarks that he has made.

    Sir, I do not believe that the Government even now know what they are doing. I believe they have blundered into something which is completely unnecessary. It is not our business in this Assembly to bring down the democratic system. We have had four years of a half-trial in

Column: 2273

a baby Austin with dual-control, and we are about to shed the driving instructor and take over. I was prepared not to press for a Commission. My Party took a decision at a Central Executive Committee meeting after the Chief Minister's offer to allow Mr Chew to resign. We were prepared to forego the trials and tribulations and the ordeals of the disclosures that are bound to take place. That will not only disgrace Mr Chew, but will disgrace the whole of the democratic process. Due to some uncontrollable impulse, the Chief Minister in a fit of anger said, "Let us go on with it." Now he thinks that since everybody on his side is getting into dirt, why not try and get the Opposition and the civil service into it also? I ask him to remember this. Ministers may come and Ministers may go, but it is our business to see that the institutions which we are establishing survive, and it is not our business to try to bring these institutions into disrepute. I welcome the remarks about people of integrity leading the country. I often feel that the Member for Serangoon - whatever his other failings - is not a dishonest man, and I think he should be the first to be distressed to discover that the Minister for Education was not the man of integrity that he would have liked, in order to give morale and tone to the service which he led. As a result not only of this disclosure but also of a series of misdemeanours which took place in his Ministry - perhaps through no fault of his - the whole of the education service and all parents whose children are in school have lost faith in the Ministry of Education. One and a half million cannot be accounted for. Defalcations-

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think probably the Member for Tanjong Pagar is wandering from this motion. We are now on disclosures in the Income Tax Department and not on disclosures in the Ministry of Education.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: That is quite so, Mr Speaker, Sir, but I wanted to endorse the point made by the Member for Serangoon, that if you want a service with tone and morale, you have to set the pace as a Minister. If you engage in mercenary activities and leave your political

Column: 2274

duties and responsibilities by the side, then you, as the political head, must be responsible for the consequences that are bound to come.

    I am sorry if this disclosure has frightened - according to the Member for Changi - corrupt diplomats from foreign countries. I hate to believe that there are corrupt diplomats from neighbouring countries. Unless it is proved to the contrary, I believe them to be honest men of integrity. But let no one be under the same misapprehension as the Member for Paya Lebar is that a P.A.P. Government will not know what is happening. The Chief Minister told us in this House that he did not know Mr Khaw Kai-Boh had already become an entitled officer and was going to quit. I did not believe him. I did not believe him because I could not believe that the Government can go on without knowing what is happening. I did not want to embarrass the Chief Secretary yesterday by asking whether he knew about the five others who applied and one who had become entitled. I did not want to press for their names. If and when it is necessary after the elections, we shall know what we want to know.
